body.header: Read these pieces of advice for Writing Task 2 and decide whether they are things you should do.

p.b: 1. What should you do before you start writing?
p.g: A Analyse the question before you start writing.
B Follow the instructions exactly.
C Make a plan.
D Spend time brainstorming for ideas before you start writing.
E Worry if you are not an expert in the subject.
F Write your ideas in the order they occur to you.
G Plan to leave time to check your composition for mistakes when you have finished writing.

p.b: 2. What should you include in your writing?
p.g: A Copy the question and use it in your introduction or conclusion.
B Give examples and evidence to support your arguments.
C Give your personal opinion.
D Include every idea you think of in your brainstorming session in your composition.
E Include jokes in your composition.
F Keep referring back to the question as you are writing.
G Make sure that everything you write is relevant to the question.
A Write a conclusion.
B Write a lot of short sentences.
C Write a minimum of 250 words.
D Write a prepared answer.
E Write a rough draft first and then rewrite it.
F Write an introduction.
G Write as legibly as you can.

p.b: 4. What type of language should you use?
p.g: A Use a linking word or phrase between every sentence.
B Use a range of grammatical structures and vocabulary.
C Use colloquial expressions.
D Use contractions.
E Use formal language.
F Use linking words and phrases between sentences and paragraphs where appropriate.
G Use topic sentences in your paragraphs.

p.b: 5. How can you achieve the best results?
p.g: A Make sweeping generalisations.
B Make up examples or evidence.
C Organise your ideas into paragraphs.
D Select the best ideas from your brainstorming session.
E Spend more than 40 minutes on Writing Task 2.
F Start writing as soon as you have read the writing task.
G Try to cover the whole subject in detail.

p.font: Otherwise you may not be answering the question correctly. Underline the keywords of the task and make sure you are clear about what kind of composition it is.
It's worth spending a few minutes to make a plan. Examiners expect to read a well organised composition that presents a logical, clearly developed argument.

If you don't do this you may find yourself searching for ideas halfway through writing. Or even worse, a great idea for the second paragraph may come to you while you've just finishing the conclusion...and then it's too late!

You are not expected to write as an expert. Task 2 can be answered by anyone with a reasonable level of general knowledge, personal opinions on a wide range of subjects and good organisational skills as a writer.
This will result in a very badly organised composition. Plan first, then write.
Always give yourself a few minutes at the end to read through and check for careless mistakes, even if you haven't quite finished writing.
This is a waste of time and words.
Remember that examples give substance to your arguments.
You don't have time or enough words to do this. Anyway, not all the points will be worth mentioning. Choose the most important.
It's good to do this in order to make sure that you are answering the question. Keep the keywords of the task in your mind while you're writing.

Be careful about this. It's very easy to think that you are answering the question when in fact you are writing things which are not relevant. Don't include things that you happen to know about the subject simply because they are interesting facts. Ask yourself, 'am I answering the questions ?'

You can't get a wide range of grammatical structures into your writing, or present intelligent arguments, if you use only very short sentences throughout your composition. However, don't write sentences which are too long either. The reader will find them too difficult to follow.
The examiner will understand immediately if you have simply memorised a composition. Even memorised phrases stand out to an experienced examiner. Have confidence in your own abilities and ideas.
You won't have time for this.
You may write a brilliant composition, but if the examiner can't read your handwriting then you've wasted your time.
You can't really write a proper argument without linking words and phrases, but that doesn't mean you should use them between every sentence. Use them only when they are necessary.
Using a variety of grammar and vocabulary will win you extra points, but they must be used appropriately.
Your writing in both Task 1 and Task 2 should be fairly formal.
This helps the reader follow the discussion and shows that you know what each of your paragraphs is about.
Don't put forward a point of view unless you can support it with a logical argument and concrete examples.
Whatever you make up probably won't be very convincing.
This is essential. It helps the reader follow your argument, and shows that you have planned your writing.
You don't need to use all of them.
Task 1 needs 20 minutes in order to be done properly.
You must spend a few minutes analysing the task, collecting ideas and planning.
This isn't possible in only 250 words.
